question: Which landforms are created by wind erosion?

content.source_1: Wind is a geomorphic agent that can erode, transport, and deposit sediment; strong winds remove loose soil and can generate dust storms that reshape arid and coastal landscapes.
content.source_2: Many introductory Earth-science texts and curricula present sand dunes and loess hills as landforms “formed by wind erosion,” emphasizing that wind moves sediment and piles it into mounds or blankets.
content.source_3: Yardangs—elongated, streamlined ridges—and deflation hollows (blowouts) are classic products of wind erosion: abrasion by sand-laden wind sculpts yardangs, and deflation excavates hollows by removing fine particles.
content.source_4: Ventifacts and pedestal (mushroom) rocks develop when windblown sand abrades rock surfaces near the ground, polishing, grooving, and undercutting them.
content.source_5: In geomorphology, dunes and loess are classed as depositional aeolian landforms (built by accumulation), whereas erosional aeolian landforms include yardangs, ventifacts, and deflation basins.
content.source_6: Wind-driven deflation during dust storms can leave behind coarse desert pavement and localized basins, direct evidence of material removal by wind erosion.
